A protocol for fast communication and file transfer over a network

Specifies how data packets are formatted, addressed, transmitted, and received

Commonly used for LAN connections

Relies on physical connection
- Usually twisted pair copper cable 
	- Range ~100m
	- Both roughly 1000 megabits/s or 1 gigabit/s (125 megabytes/s)
		- Normal Ethernet = 10 megabits/s (1 mb/s)
		- Fast Ethernet = 100 megabits/s (12 mb/s)
		- Gigabit Ethernet = 1 gb/s (125 mb/s)
	- 4 pairs total
	- [[Cat5e]]: just modem to pc; 10x better than cat5
	- [[Cat6]]: backbone;
	- [![500FT SFTP Copper CAT7 Ethernet Cable Bulk , Satmaximum](https://encrypted-tbn0.gstatic.com/images?q=tbn:ANd9GcSnfh7XPw-T-6pi0ePyHPJGRp6uj-cQIYoWlw&usqp=CAU)]

[[Ethernet Switches]]
- Switch
- Interconnect multiple devices within a LAN
- Facilitates proper routing of packets to intended destinations
- [![Amazon.com: NETGEAR 5-Port Gigabit Ethernet Unmanaged Switch (GS305) - Home  Network Hub, Office Ethernet Splitter, Plug-and-Play, Silent Operation,  Desktop or Wall Mount : Electronics](data:image/jpeg;base64,)]


[[POE]]: Power Over Ethernet 
- Not only transfers data but also power
- Security camera, wireless access point
- Power provided at switch
	- If no support on router, power-injector [[Midspan]]
- Original: IEEE 802.3af 
	- Now rolled into 802.3
	- POE+: IEEE 802.3at
	- POE++: IEEE 802.3bt
